tentpoles.description: Professor Jonathan Sterling found dead in his study - apparent heart attack. Reeves notices tiny inconsistencies that suggest murder, but Dr. Chen's autopsy shows natural causes. Reeves refuses to close the case.

Reeves discovers Sterling was systematically destroying careers of former students. Dr. Harrington emerges as a suspect with motive - but she has a perfect alibi and all forensics still show natural death. Reeves realizes he might never prove it was murder.

Ethan Cross finds a microscopic puncture mark hidden in Sterling's scalp. Dr. Chen confirms: someone injected something that mimicked cardiac arrest. It WAS murder. But the poison is undetectable and already degraded. Now Reeves knows HOW but still can't prove WHO.

Reeves sets a trap: he tells each suspect privately that the poison was found. Only Dr. Harrington reacts with precise knowledge she shouldn't have. In the confrontation, she confesses - Sterling was destroying lives for ego. She chose mercy killing over exposing him and ruining more careers posthumously.

Reeves has the confession but faces an impossible choice: prosecute a doctor who saved future victims from a cruel man, or let the perfect murder stand. He chooses truth - arrests her but testifies to the mitigating circumstances. Justice served, but hollow victory. Sterling's victims come forward, validating Harrington's motives.
